content.body:
> <@gsnedders:mozilla.org> I think my biggest question is whether the length markers are meaningful; I don't think there's any difference in vowel length between common en-gb and en-us within "what"?

Do you mean e.g. the /ɑː/ in /wɑːt/?
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @gsnedders:mozilla.org
I think my biggest question is whether the length markers are meaningful; I don't think there's any difference in vowel length between common en-gb and en-us within "what"?
Do you mean e.g. the /ɑː/ in /wɑːt/?

content.body: You must be right since there's only one vowel sound in <what>. If there could possibly be a meaning to vowel stress in a single-syllable word, it would have to be about its role in the cadence of a larger utterance.

In Pink Floyd's "Us and Them" https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HoLhKJuGhK0 David sings "And who'll deny it's what the fighting's all about?" You can hear the distinctive British [t] throughout the song, but in fact at 7:10 you can hear him sing "what" as /wɑɾ/, which isn't listed at all on Wiktionary! Oh well... There are more dialects in the British Isles than there are grains of sand on the beach.

> <@meghanbun:matrix.org> somewhat related to https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10483 is there any interest in using function names for abstract operations like in ES as opposed to the current sentence ones (eg https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#convert-to-premultiplied)

No, I think the function names are unnecessarily hard to read.
content.formatted_body:
In reply to @meghanbun:matrix.org
somewhat related to https://github.com/whatwg/html/issues/10483 is there any interest in using function names for abstract operations like in ES as opposed to the current sentence ones (eg https://html.spec.whatwg.org/#convert-to-premultiplied)
No, I think the function names are unnecessarily hard to read.

content.body: in what way, arent they describing algorithms?
https://dom.spec.whatwg.org/#concept-create-element is a better example of one
I guess it’s more that they’re _naming_ the algorithms rather than _describing_ the algorithms.
content.formatted_body: I guess it’s more that they’re naming the algorithms rather than describing the algorithms.

content.body: With the current prose style, the prose describes the algorithms in natural language.
Replacing the prose description with just a name seems like a regression in expressiveness.
At least it seems like a regression in readability.
But I can understand that some would find the prose descriptions the algorithms are labeled with the be more unwieldy than having them labeled with short names.

I guess it’s definitely more *idiosyncratic* for a spec to have callable prose-description labels for algorithms. I don’t actually know any other specs which do that, in places outside web-platform specs.
content.formatted_body: I guess it’s definitely more idiosyncratic for a spec to have callable prose-description labels for algorithms. I don’t actually know any other specs which do that, in places outside web-platform specs.

content.body: But then, as far as that goes, there’s a lot of stuff the HTML spec does differently than most other specs. And I think there was a time when it really was _the_ only spec that did this callable-prose-description-label thing. But since that time, other web-platform specs have adopted the same style. (At least I _think_ HTML was the first to do it, in our world at least)
content.formatted_body: But then, as far as that goes, there’s a lot of stuff the HTML spec does differently than most other specs. And I think there was a time when it really was the only spec that did this callable-prose-description-label thing. But since that time, other web-platform specs have adopted the same style. (At least I think HTML was the first to do it, in our world at least)

content.body: * With the current callable prose-description-label style, the prose labels describe the algorithms in natural language.

m.new_content.body: With the current callable prose-description-label style, the prose labels describe the algorithms in natural language.

content.body: * Replacing the prose-description label with just a name seems like a regression in expressiveness.

m.new_content.body: Replacing the prose-description label with just a name seems like a regression in expressiveness.

content.body: * But I can understand that some would find the prose descriptions the algorithms are labeled with to be more unwieldy than having them labeled with short names.
